Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Fitness can be measured as the number of offspring produced by an individual and is determined by an individualâ€™s genetic makeup and the environment. For a population to remain stable, each generation of individuals must produce a sufficient number of offspring. This research will investigate the relative roles of individual genetic makeup and the environment in determining fitness for a population of banner-tailed kangaroo rats. The results from this work will be used to create a model designed to predict how fitness, and therefore population stability, respond to changes in the environment and the genetic properties of a population. This research will shed light on a fundamental question in evolutionary biology (how fitness is determined) while also informing conservation and population management strategies. Describing influences on individual fitness will allow for more robust predictions of long-term stability for populations threatened by environmental change or small population size. Outreach will include a report and a web-based application to relate population genetics concepts to the public. This will be available as a curriculum plan, reaching a diverse group of educators and students.

The samples to be analyzed in this project are derived from a fully pedigreed population of banner-tailed kangaroo rats that has been monitored since 1980. The Fellow will leverage existing long-term data on this population (familial relationships and lifetime fitness estimates), generate new whole genomic sequence data, and incorporate remote sensing data to identify how genomic variants interact with phenotypes and environmental characteristics to determine individual fitness and, consequently, long-term population stability. These empirical results will be used to parameterize a spatially-explicit, agent-based model generalizable to other natural systems that can be used to predict the effects of changes in population (e.g., inbreeding, dispersal distances, migration rates) and environmental properties (e.g., resource availability over space) on population stability. Because samples used in this research were collected from private land, the project will include communicating results and discussing land management implications with landowners. The results of this project will also be used to build a web application and associated educational materials designed to teach undergraduate students concepts of population and conservation genetics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to describe relationships among fitness, genetics, and the environment for individuals belonging to a pedigreed wild population of banner-tailed kangaroo rats.

 

The first specific objective of this research was to link specific genomic variation to individual fitness by sequencing pairs of mates with differential reproductive success. However, when we examined multiple whole-genome measures of individual inbreeding and relatedness between mates, we found no significant relationships between these estimates and individual or mate pair fitness. This objective is being further pursued by a graduate student in the lab who is also incorporating genome-wide methylation data to test whether epigenetic patterns may explain differential fitness.

 

The second objective was to test whether and how an individual’s local environment influences reproductive outcomes. To our knowledge, this objective resulted in the first peer-reviewed publication directly linking satellite-based remote sensing data to measures of individual fitness. We found that surface temperature corresponded to decreased individual fitness (i.e., the number of offspring produced by an individual) but also led to an increased number of active mounds in the population—a reliably proxy for population size in this species. That our results contrasted across sampling scales demonstrates that the environmental mechanisms driving individual fitness and, consequently, long-term population dynamics may be mis- or undercharacterized if only measured at single spatial or temporal scales.

 

The final objective was to summarize the identified relationships among fitness, genetics, and the environment via modeling. However, because we could not yet parameterize the relationship between genetics and fitness with our empirical data, a separate modeling study was conducted using a forward-time, whole-genome evolutionary approach. This project simulated multiple population demographic histories (e.g., a population that has remained large for a long period of time, a population that has undergone a bottleneck), described how these differing histories affected specific patterns of genomic variation, and tested the accuracy of various methodologies for detecting these patterns. The outcome of this project were specific recommendations for other researchers seeking to analyzed and apply these patterns in conservation contexts.

 

This award has produced two first-authored publications for the PI, with a third currently in review and a forthcoming fourth paper linking genetic, epigenetic, and fitness data. During the course of this fellowship, the PI delivered 3 invited and 2 contributed conference presentations, mentored 5 graduate students, and served as an DNA extraction activity leader for a non-profit educational organization supporting traditionally underrepresented students.
